cluster_classes.class_description: Intrinsic morphological and visual characteristics of butterfly eggs, including their size, shape, and color, which vary among species.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: The size, shape, and color of butterfly eggs vary depending on the species.

members.entity_description: Variation in how large or small butterfly eggs are across species.
Morphological forms of butterfly eggs such as round, cylindrical, or oval.
Observed colors of butterfly eggs, including white, yellow, green, and brown.

cluster_classes.class_description: Taxonomic categories of butterflies and caterpillars at the species level, used to explain variation in traits such as shape, color, and lifespan.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: Different biological species of caterpillars and distinct taxonomic species of butterflies.

members.entity_description: Different biological species of caterpillars that determine their varied shapes, sizes, and colors.
Distinct taxonomic species of butterflies whose traits, such as lifespan, can vary among them.

cluster_classes.class_description: Adult butterflies as whole organisms, including general references to butterflies and sex-specific subsets such as females that lay eggs.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: adult butterflies, including female butterflies that lay eggs on host plants

members.entity_description: A butterfly, an insect of the order Lepidoptera that undergoes complete metamorphosis through egg, larva (caterpillar), pupa (chrysalis), and adult stages.
Adult butterflies of the female sex that lay eggs on specific host plants to begin the next generation.

remarks: This class is now empty after splitting its members into more precise classes. Prefer using 'Adult butterflies (all sexes)' or 'Female butterflies' going forward.

splits.name: Adult butterflies (all sexes)
splits.description: Adult butterflies as whole organisms, without specifying sex; includes general references to butterflies in the adult life stage.

splits.name: Female butterflies
splits.description: Adult butterflies of the female sex that lay eggs on specific host plants to begin the next generation.

args.justification: The original 'Adult Butterflies' class bundles a general organism concept and a sex-specific subset ('female butterflies'); splitting yields two more coherent organism classes.

args.new_description: Legacy aggregate class that previously bundled general adult butterflies and female butterflies; concepts have been split into dedicated classes and this class is retained only for backward compatibility.
args.remark: This class is now empty after splitting its members into more precise classes. Prefer using 'Adult butterflies (all sexes)' or 'Female butterflies' going forward.
args.justification: After splitting its members into more specific classes, the original class should be clearly marked as a legacy aggregate and aligned to the same butterfly-focused class group.

args.new_description: Adult butterflies as whole organisms, regardless of sex, representing the adult life stage of butterflies.
args.justification: The new split class representing all adult butterflies should be given a clean canonical name and attached to the butterfly-focused class group.

args.new_description: Adult butterflies of the female sex that lay eggs on specific host plants to begin the next generation.
args.justification: The sex-specific subset of adult butterflies merits its own organism class and should be aligned under the same butterfly biology class group.
Butterfly egg size, shape, and color are intrinsic traits within the same biological domain as the other butterfly-related classes and should share a common 'Butterfly Biology' class group.

args.new_description: Taxonomic species of butterflies and their caterpillar (larval) stages, used to explain variation in traits such as shape, color, and lifespan.
args.justification: This class represents species-level taxa for butterflies and caterpillars; renaming and setting class_type_hint to 'Taxon' clarifies its scope while attaching it to the shared 'Butterfly Biology' class group.

executed_decisions.justification: The original 'Adult Butterflies' class bundles a general organism concept and a sex-specific subset ('female butterflies'); splitting yields two more coherent organism classes.

executed_decisions.new_description: Legacy aggregate class that previously bundled general adult butterflies and female butterflies; concepts have been split into dedicated classes and this class is retained only for backward compatibility.
executed_decisions.remark: This class is now empty after splitting its members into more precise classes. Prefer using 'Adult butterflies (all sexes)' or 'Female butterflies' going forward.
executed_decisions.justification: After splitting its members into more specific classes, the original class should be clearly marked as a legacy aggregate and aligned to the same butterfly-focused class group.

executed_decisions.justification: The new split class representing all adult butterflies should be given a clean canonical name and attached to the butterfly-focused class group.

executed_decisions.new_description: Adult butterflies of the female sex that lay eggs on specific host plants to begin the next generation.
executed_decisions.justification: The sex-specific subset of adult butterflies merits its own organism class and should be aligned under the same butterfly biology class group.
Butterfly egg size, shape, and color are intrinsic traits within the same biological domain as the other butterfly-related classes and should share a common 'Butterfly Biology' class group.
